text: It's more of a question of which forecast horizons do we appear to have some edge in our ability to forecast. And it typically is a range. You're holding everything else constant. You're using these models to forecast out a sample over different forecast horizons. So typically what you'll see is that there's a range where netting out costs. Keep in mind, when you're forecasting over a one-day horizon, typically your turnover is going to be a lot higher than if you're forecasting over a five-day horizon or a 20-day horizon. It's not just is your forecast accuracy higher, but can you capture that edge after netting out expected trading costs? That needs to factor into it. But notwithstanding that, you're observing a wide variety of different forecast horizons. And you're saying we can't really distinguish between the ability to forecast over one-day, two-day, three-day, four-day, five-day. We can say it doesn't look like there's any forecast horizon out beyond a certain forecast period. We'll just take all models over the forecast horizons where we appear to have an edge. And then as we're setting expectations, we're using all of the information from the variance that we observe in each of those forecast horizons to expand the cone of potential expectation that we want to see as we observe the strategy in live trading. So that cone of potential expectation expands and contracts as you learn more about the market. And then as we're setting expectations, we're using all of the information from the variance that we observe in each of those forecast horizons to expand the cone of potential expectation that we want to see as we observe the strategy in live trading. So that's the main thing about the variables that explain forward returns and all of the hyperparameters that are required in order to translate a traditional kind of empirical finance hypothesis test into a final investment strategy that you deploy in live trading.
